STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 18, 2021
Brandon Hannah
Ennis Center for Children - Flint
129 E. Third
Flint, MI 48502
RE: License #: CB250201108
Ennis Center for Children - Flint
129 E. Third
Flint, MI 48502
Dear Mr. Hannah:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 19-28, 2021. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Alicia Wiggins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 917-1048
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule
annually for the duration of the child's placement.
(1)(c) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the initial evaluation did
not have written endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
(1)(d) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the current reevaluation
did not have written endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
(2) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, which required annual
documentation, the Foster Parent Agency Agreement for 2020 was not located in
the record.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
4

(5)(d) In two out of five special evaluations reviewed, the last names of the children
who were interviewed were included in the report.
(6)(b) In one out of five special evaluations reviewed, the foster parent was not
informed, in writing, that he or she has a right to have his or her written response
included as an attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
(6)(c) In two out of five special evaluations reviewed, the agency did not provide a
copy of the report to the social services worker that had children placed in the home
at the time of the special evaluation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (5)(d)—2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP
approved February 19, 2019.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, updated service plans (USP)
were not completed at least once every 90 calendar days. One USP was due on
April 22, 2020 and it was completed on April 25, 2020. One USP was due on
October 19, 2020 and it was completed on October 20, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
February 19, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
May 5 , 2020.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
In three out of six adoption family assessments reviewed, the adoptive family
assessments were not written within 90 days of the family signing an application.
 One adoption applicant signed an application on July 27, 2019 and the
adoption family assessment was written on March 26, 2020.
 One adoption applicant signed an application on January 22, 2020 and the
adoption family assessment was written on July 30, 2020.
 One adoption applicant signed an application on April 4, 2020 and the
adoption family assessment was written on October 5, 2020.
5

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
May 5 , 2020.
MCL 722.112a Child caring institution, foster family home, foster family
group home, child care center, group child care home, and
family child care home; individual certified in first aid and
cardiopulmonary resuscitation; applicability of MCL
722.125.
(1) A child caring institution, foster family home, foster family
group home, child care center, group child care home, and
family child care home shall have individuals present, as
prescribed in the appropriate administrative rules, who have
current certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary
resuscitation obtained through the American Red Cross, the
American Heart Association, or an equivalent organization or
institution approved by the department.
In one out of eight foster home records reviewed, the CPR and first aid training
expired on July 7, 2020. The foster parent completed CPR and first aid training on
January 22, 2021.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
MDHHS Policy Personnel Training.
SRM 200
All personnel, contractors, vendors and external auditors who
have access to CW-CHRI are required to complete security
awareness training (SAT). Training will be available on the
Learning Management System (LMS) for MDHHS personnel
and contractors with access to this system.
SAT is required to be taken within six months of being in a
position with CW-CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all personnel with CHRI
access completes the SAT. DCWL consultants will monitor
completion of SAT in all CPAs as part of the annual licensing
audit.
6

CI-182a was released to the field in December of 2016 advising
all current employees with access to CHRI to complete SAT
training no later than 02/10/2017. All other employees hired
after December of 2016 were required to complete SAT
according to the policy.
There were six employees found to be in non-compliance to timely certification of
Security Awareness Training (SAT).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
February 19, 2019.
MDHHS Policy Placement Exception Requests (PER).
FOM 722-03E
A placement must not be made if it will result in one of the
following:
 More than three foster children in that foster home.
 More than six total children, including the foster family’s
birth and/or adopted children.
 More than three children under the age of three residing
in a foster home.
 Siblings placed apart
Exceptions to these limitations may be made on an individual
basis when it is determined to be in the best interest of the child
being placed.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which siblings were placed
apart, a placement exception request was completed but was still pending approval
at the time of the Renewal Inspection.
MDHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
• Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement preservation/disruption - At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later than
7

three business days after an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down from
a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or request
for change in foster home/relative placements.
Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
In one out eight foster children’s records reviewed, a FTM for case service plan
development for the ISP was not completed within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. The ISP was due on December 10, 2020 and the FTM was
completed on December 14, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
February 19, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
May 5 , 2020.
MDHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
FOM 722-06H
For each child with a permanency goal of reunification, the
child’s assigned caseworker must have face-to face contact with
the child’s parent/guardian as follows:
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
with each parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in
the parent’s residence. One of the face-to-face contacts must be
used to discuss the following:
• Petition and court orders.
• Case service plan.
• Family Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
• Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
• Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement.
• Scheduling and expectations of parenting time.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
8

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which there was parent
involvement, there were no face-to-face contacts with the birth mother in September
2020 and October 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
May 5 , 2020.
MDHHS Policy Timely Entry of Caseworker Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this
includes attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all
pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within
five business days of the contact. This includes the following:
• Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
• Foster care worker.
• CPS worker.
• Adoption worker.
• Permanency resource monitors.
• Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
• Sibling/child face-to face contacts.
In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all contacts were not entered
in MiSACWIS within five business days of the contact.
 For one foster child’s record, the face-to-face contact with the secondary
caregiver was completed on August 28, 2020 and it was entered in
MiSACWIS on January 27, 2021.
 For one foster child’s record, the face-to-face contact with the birth mother
was completed on May 18, 2020 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on January
27, 2021. The June 2020 contact with the birth mother was completed via
phone on June 11, 2020 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on January 27,
2021. The sibling visit occurred on June 17, 2020 and it was entered in
MiSACWIS on January 27, 2021.
 For one foster child’s record, the face-to-face contact with the birth father was
completed on July 20, 2020 and it was entered in MiSACWIS on January 27,
2021.
MDHHS Policy Foster Care – Initial Service Plan (ISP)
FOM 722-08
Prior to finalizing, the ISP along with the required assessments
must be reviewed and approved by the foster care supervisor
only after a face-to-face meeting with the foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
9

 Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of
the Report Date.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the ISP was not approved by
the supervisor within 14 calendar days of the report date. The ISP was completed on
December 10, 2020 and it was approved on January 19, 2021.
DHHS Policy Supervisory Approval: Updated Service Plans.
FOM 722-09
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required assessments
(FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and approved by the
foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face meeting with the
foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of
the report date.
In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the USP was not approved
by the supervisor within 14 calendar days of the report date.
 For one foster child’s record, the report was completed on November 4, 2020
and it was approved on January 14, 2021.
 For one foster child’s record, the report was completed on November 2, 2020
and it was approved on November 18, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, one report was completed on April 25, 2020 and
it was approved on May 12, 2020. One report was completed on October 20,
2020 and it was approved on November 6, 2020.
In one out of one independent living records reviewed, the USP was not approved
by the supervisor within 14 calendar days of the report date.
 For one independent living record, the report was completed on January 5,
2021 and it was approved on January 27, 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
February 19, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
May 5 , 2020.
DHHS Policy Educational Services: Documentation of Educational
FOM 723 Requirements.
All educational information and related tasks, activities, and
contacts must be documented within the social work contacts,
case service plans, placement, and the education section of
MiSACWIS.
10

The education section of MiSACWIS should be updated at the
end of each school year to reflect when a child completes a
grade and advances to the next or if they are repeating the
same grade. Each school year should be end dated with an end
grade listed.
In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, which were school aged
children, there was no supporting documentation (e.g. last report card) of the
children’s education status in MiSACWIS.
MDHHS Policy Health Requirements: Periodicity Schedule.
FOM 801-01
After the initial medical examination upon entering foster care,
all children require an EPSDT/well child exam according to the
periodicity schedule recommended by the American Academy
of Pediatrics.
 For children under 3 years old, the periodicity schedule
for EPSDT/well child exams is as follows:
Newborn - 1 week of age.
4 weeks of age.
2 months of age.
4 months of age.
6 months of age.
9 months of age.
12 months of age.
15 months of age.
18 months of age.
24 months of age.
30 months of age.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which the foster child was
under three years old, there was no documentation of a two month well child exam
being completed.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports.
FOM 801-03
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided to the foster care provider within two weeks of
the child's placement date. The actual date the foster care
provider receives the medical passport must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
11

Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the medical passports were not
provided to the child’s foster care provider per the timeframes specified in the policy.
 For one foster child’s record, the foster child was replaced to a foster home
on August 28, 2020 and the foster parent signed the medical passport on
October 29, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the foster child was placed in the foster home on
December 6, 2019. The agency accepted the case on September 1, 2020.
The foster parent signed the medical passport on November 13, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
February 19, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
May 5 , 2020.
MDHHS Policy Child Adoption Assessment.
ADM 300
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be completed
by the adoption worker and approved by the adoption
supervisor within 45 calendar days of case acceptance.
12

In three out of eight adoption records reviewed, the child adoption assessments
were not completed by the adoption worker and approved by the adoption
supervisor within 45 calendar days of case acceptance.
 For one adoption record, the case was accepted on January 22, 2020 and the
child adoption assessment was approved on May 13, 2020.
 For one adoption record, the case was accepted on March 16, 2020 and the
child adoption assessment was approved on May 14, 2020.
 For one adoption record, the case was accepted on December 7, 2020 and
the child adoption assessment was still pending approval at the time of the
Renewal Inspection.
MDHHS Policy Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports.
ADM 330
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
Note: When the child adoption assessment is used as the
initial quarterly report, the next quarterly report is due 90
calendar days from completion of the child adoption
assessment. When the child adoption assessment is not
completed within the initial required quarterly reporting period,
the DHS-614 is due 90 calendar days from case acceptance or
90 days after the order terminating parental rights is signed,
whichever is later.
In one out of eight adoption records reviewed, the quarterly adoption progress
reports were not completed timely. The adoption case was accepted on March 16,
2020. The first quarterly report due date was July 30, 2020 and the report was
completed on August 5, 2020. The second quarterly report due date was October
29, 2020 and the report was completed on November 2, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2020 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
May 5 , 2020.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
13

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency received a complaint on March 17, 2020. The allegation was that a
former foster child would get “whooped” on their hands with hangers by the foster
parent. It was determined that the foster parent admitted to instructing an older
foster child once or twice to “whoop” the other foster children. The foster home was
found to be in non-compliance of R 400.9403 Foster parent duties. The agency
recommended no change in the foster home’s license upon receipt of an acceptable
corrective action plan (CAP). The CAP included the foster parent reviewing, signing
and agreeing to follow a safety plan regarding appropriate discipline methods. The
agency’s handling of this special evaluation was appropriate.
The agency received a complaint on October 9, 2020. One allegation was that the
foster parent did not give the children in her home their presents or money from their
family. A second allegation was that the foster parent took away the children's
phones that their family bought them because the foster parent does not want the
children to record her. A third allegation was that the foster parent curses at the
children. A fourth allegation was that sometime in March 2020, the foster parent told
one of the foster children, while in the school office, "Shut up. You're mom is dead."
It was reported that the foster parent often commented to the foster children that
their mother is dead when she was upset with them. The last allegation was that the
foster parent was upset on October 9, 2020, hit one foster child in the face with a
belt and hit another foster child with a belt on his arms and legs. It was determined
that the foster parent admitted to making threats of physical discipline, which is
against the agency’s behavior management policy. The foster home was found to be
in non-compliance of R 400.9201(j) Foster home applicant/licensee qualifications
and R 400.9403 (d)(i) Foster parent duties. The agency recommended no change in
the foster home’s license upon receipt of an acceptable CAP. The CAP included the
licensing worker reviewing the agency’s behavior management policy with the foster
parent and the foster parent signing and agreeing to follow the policy. The agency’s
handling of this special evaluation was appropriate.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a CAP on February 19, 2019 for the Renewal Inspection that
was completed in January 2019. The CAP was approved on February 19, 2019. The
agency is in non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the agency received
repeat violations for the following, during the current Renewal Inspection:
 R 400.12327 (5)(d) Special evaluation
14

 R 400.12418 (2)(b) Development of service plans
 DHHS Policy SRM 200 Personnel Training
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-03 Placement Exception Requests (PER)
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval: Updated Service Plans
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
The agency submitted a CAP on May 5, 2020 for the Interim Inspection that was
completed in March 2020. The CAP was approved on May 5, 2020. The agency is in
non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the agency received repeat violations
for the following, during the current Renewal Inspection:
 R 400.12418 (2)(b) Development of service plans
 R 400.12605 (1) Adoptive family evaluation
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Timely Entry of Caseworker Contacts
 MDHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s)
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval: Updated Service Plans
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
 MDHHS Policy ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
February 10, 2021
________________________________________
Alicia Wiggins Date
Licensing Consultant
15

Approved By:
February 18, 2021
